speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: SCENE III. The tent of Coriolanus.

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Enter CORIOLANUS, AUFIDIUS, and others

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: We will before the walls of Rome tomorrow

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Set down our host. My partner in this action,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: You must report to the Volscian lords, how plainly

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I have borne this business.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Only their ends

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: You have respected; stopp'd your ears against

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: The general suit of Rome; never admitted

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: A private whisper, no, not with such friends

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: That thought them sure of you.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: This last old man,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Whom with a crack'd heart I have sent to Rome,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Loved me above the measure of a father;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Nay, godded me, indeed. Their latest refuge

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Was to send him; for whose old love I have,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Though I show'd sourly to him, once more offer'd

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The first conditions, which they did refuse

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And cannot now accept; to grace him only

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That thought he could do more, a very little

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I have yielded to: fresh embassies and suits,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Nor from the state nor private friends, hereafter

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Will I lend ear to. Ha! what shout is this?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Shout within

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Shall I be tempted to infringe my vow

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: In the same time 'tis made? I will not.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Enter in mourning habits, VIRGILIA, VOLUMNIA, leading young MARCIUS, VALERIA, and Attendants

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: My wife comes foremost; then the honour'd mould

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Wherein this trunk was framed, and in her hand

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The grandchild to her blood. But, out, affection!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: All bond and privilege of nature, break!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Let it be virtuous to be obstinate.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: What is that curt'sy worth? or those doves' eyes,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Which can make gods forsworn? I melt, and am not

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Of stronger earth than others. My mother bows;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: As if Olympus to a molehill should

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: In supplication nod: and my young boy

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Hath an aspect of intercession, which

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Great nature cries 'Deny not.' let the Volsces

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Plough Rome and harrow Italy: I'll never

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Be such a gosling to obey instinct, but stand,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: As if a man were author of himself

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And knew no other kin.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: My lord and husband!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: These eyes are not the same I wore in Rome.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: The sorrow that delivers us thus changed

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: Makes you think so.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Like a dull actor now,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I have forgot my part, and I am out,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Even to a full disgrace. Best of my flesh,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Forgive my tyranny; but do not say

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: For that 'Forgive our Romans.' O, a kiss

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Long as my exile, sweet as my revenge!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Now, by the jealous queen of heaven, that kiss

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I carried from thee, dear; and my true lip

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Hath virgin'd it e'er since. You gods! I prate,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And the most noble mother of the world

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Leave unsaluted: sink, my knee, i' the earth;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Kneels

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Of thy deep duty more impression show

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Than that of common sons.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: O, stand up blest!

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Whilst, with no softer cushion than the flint,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: I kneel before thee; and unproperly

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Show duty, as mistaken all this while

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Between the child and parent.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Kneels

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: What is this?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Your knees to me? to your corrected son?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Then let the pebbles on the hungry beach

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Fillip the stars; then let the mutinous winds

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Strike the proud cedars 'gainst the fiery sun;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Murdering impossibility, to make

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: What cannot be, slight work.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Thou art my warrior;

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: I holp to frame thee. Do you know this lady?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The noble sister of Publicola,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The moon of Rome, chaste as the icicle

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That's curdied by the frost from purest snow

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And hangs on Dian's temple: dear Valeria!

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: This is a poor epitome of yours,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Which by the interpretation of full time

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: May show like all yourself.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The god of soldiers,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: With the consent of supreme Jove, inform

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Thy thoughts with nobleness; that thou mayst prove

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To shame unvulnerable, and stick i' the wars

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Like a great sea-mark, standing every flaw,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And saving those that eye thee!

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Your knee, sirrah.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That's my brave boy!

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Even he, your wife, this lady, and myself,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Are suitors to you.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I beseech you, peace:

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Or, if you'ld ask, remember this before:

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The thing I have forsworn to grant may never

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Be held by you denials. Do not bid me

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Dismiss my soldiers, or capitulate

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Again with Rome's mechanics: tell me not

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Wherein I seem unnatural: desire not

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To ally my rages and revenges with

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Your colder reasons.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: O, no more, no more!

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: You have said you will not grant us any thing;

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: For we have nothing else to ask, but that

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Which you deny already: yet we will ask;

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: That, if you fail in our request, the blame

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: May hang upon your hardness: therefore hear us.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Aufidius, and you Volsces, mark; for we'll

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Hear nought from Rome in private. Your request?

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Should we be silent and not speak, our raiment

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: And state of bodies would bewray what life

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: We have led since thy exile. Think with thyself

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: How more unfortunate than all living women

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Are we come hither: since that thy sight,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: which should

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Make our eyes flow with joy, hearts dance

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: with comforts,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Constrains them weep and shake with fear and sorrow;

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Making the mother, wife and child to see

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: The son, the husband and the father tearing

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: His country's bowels out. And to poor we

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Thine enmity's most capital: thou barr'st us

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Our prayers to the gods, which is a comfort

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: That all but we enjoy; for how can we,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Alas, how can we for our country pray.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Whereto we are bound, together with thy victory,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Whereto we are bound? alack, or we must lose

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: The country, our dear nurse, or else thy person,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Our comfort in the country. We must find

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: An evident calamity, though we had

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Our wish, which side should win: for either thou

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Must, as a foreign recreant, be led

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: With manacles thorough our streets, or else

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: triumphantly tread on thy country's ruin,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: And bear the palm for having bravely shed

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Thy wife and children's blood. For myself, son,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: I purpose not to wait on fortune till

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: These wars determine: if I cannot persuade thee

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Rather to show a noble grace to both parts

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Than seek the end of one, thou shalt no sooner

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: March to assault thy country than to tread--

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Trust to't, thou shalt not--on thy mother's womb,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: That brought thee to this world.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: Ay, and mine,

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: That brought you forth this boy, to keep your name

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: Living to time.

speaker: Young MARCIUS
text_entry: A' shall not tread on me;

speaker: Young MARCIUS
text_entry: I'll run away till I am bigger, but then I'll fight.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Not of a woman's tenderness to be,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Requires nor child nor woman's face to see.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I have sat too long.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Rising

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Nay, go not from us thus.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: If it were so that our request did tend

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: To save the Romans, thereby to destroy

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: The Volsces whom you serve, you might condemn us,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: As poisonous of your honour: no; our suit

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Is that you reconcile them: while the Volsces

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: May say 'This mercy we have show'd;' the Romans,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: 'This we received;' and each in either side

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Give the all-hail to thee and cry 'Be blest

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: For making up this peace!' Thou know'st, great son,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: The end of war's uncertain, but this certain,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: That, if thou conquer Rome, the benefit

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Which thou shalt thereby reap is such a name,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Whose repetition will be dogg'd with curses;

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Whose chronicle thus writ: 'The man was noble,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: But with his last attempt he wiped it out;

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Destroy'd his country, and his name remains

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: To the ensuing age abhorr'd.' Speak to me, son:

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Thou hast affected the fine strains of honour,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: To imitate the graces of the gods;

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: To tear with thunder the wide cheeks o' the air,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: And yet to charge thy sulphur with a bolt

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: That should but rive an oak. Why dost not speak?

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Think'st thou it honourable for a noble man

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Still to remember wrongs? Daughter, speak you:

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: He cares not for your weeping. Speak thou, boy:

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Perhaps thy childishness will move him more

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Than can our reasons. There's no man in the world

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: More bound to 's mother; yet here he lets me prate

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Like one i' the stocks. Thou hast never in thy life

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Show'd thy dear mother any courtesy,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: When she, poor hen, fond of no second brood,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Has cluck'd thee to the wars and safely home,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Loaden with honour. Say my request's unjust,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: And spurn me back: but if it be not so,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Thou art not honest; and the gods will plague thee,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: That thou restrain'st from me the duty which

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: To a mother's part belongs. He turns away:

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Down, ladies; let us shame him with our knees.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: To his surname Coriolanus 'longs more pride

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Than pity to our prayers. Down: an end;

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: This is the last: so we will home to Rome,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: And die among our neighbours. Nay, behold 's:

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: This boy, that cannot tell what he would have

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: But kneels and holds up bands for fellowship,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Does reason our petition with more strength

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Than thou hast to deny 't. Come, let us go:

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: This fellow had a Volscian to his mother;

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: His wife is in Corioli and his child

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Like him by chance. Yet give us our dispatch:

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: I am hush'd until our city be a-fire,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: And then I'll speak a little.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: He holds her by the hand, silent

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: O mother, mother!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: What have you done? Behold, the heavens do ope,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The gods look down, and this unnatural scene

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: They laugh at. O my mother, mother! O!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: You have won a happy victory to Rome;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: But, for your son,--believe it, O, believe it,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Most dangerously you have with him prevail'd,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: If not most mortal to him. But, let it come.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Aufidius, though I cannot make true wars,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I'll frame convenient peace. Now, good Aufidius,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Were you in my stead, would you have heard

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: A mother less? or granted less, Aufidius?

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: I was moved withal.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I dare be sworn you were:

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And, sir, it is no little thing to make

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Mine eyes to sweat compassion. But, good sir,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: What peace you'll make, advise me: for my part,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I'll not to Rome, I'll back with you; and pray you,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Stand to me in this cause. O mother! wife!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: [Aside]  I am glad thou hast set thy mercy and

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: thy honour

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: At difference in thee: out of that I'll work

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Myself a former fortune.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: The Ladies make signs to CORIOLANUS

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Ay, by and by;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To VOLUMNIA, VIRGILIA,  and c

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: But we will drink together; and you shall bear

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: A better witness back than words, which we,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: On like conditions, will have counter-seal'd.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Come, enter with us. Ladies, you deserve

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To have a temple built you: all the swords

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: In Italy, and her confederate arms,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Could not have made this peace.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Exeunt
